posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked:
Hello, we are currently “trying” to manually tune our cascading elevator. We are having issues that we want to resolve. For reference, here is a link to our code (everything is in TrapezoidProfile branch). We want to make sure our code is correctly set up.

Here’s our issue: as we continued to tune our values, we noticed that the elevator did not move to the same position if we reran it with the same tuning values, showcasing inconsistencies. Sometimes, it overshot and sometimes undershot the position setpoint in a subsequent trial. Is this normal during the tuning process? We made sure to follow manual tuning procedures (like doing kG/kS first, then kV, etc.) Also, we do not know if this is a mechanical issue.  Here is a video of how our elevator looks.

Could anything mechanical affect feedforward/ PID at all? Or is our issue mainly software? Any suggestions are appreciated.

Side note: if you notice in our code, we have our elevator setpoints in units of rotations. We are confused about how to convert it to linear distance because we noticed one motor rotation does not translate to a specific linear distance (Ex, one rotation was 2.25 in, but four rotations were 13 in of linear distance).

Run some integral control. It sounds like you are experiencing steady-state error caused by friction and an imperfect mechanical system, which integral control will eliminate. Correctly tuning kS and/or making the controller more aggressive can also help improve it, but integral control is the only way to 100% eliminate it.

Belal_4641:

(Ex, one rotation was 2.25 in, but four rotations were 13 in of linear distance)

These are imperfections in the rigging. Make sure all runs are perfectly straight and that your spool has a low fleet angle and inly 1 set of wraps.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Always calibrate your motion over the largest possible span…  That usually improves things!

Sounds like your feedback is not really removing the error.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Sorry for the late reply. That makes sense! So, I’m assuming it is expected to experience this during the process of tuning our values? To clarify, we saw these inconsistencies when we only had kG, kS, and kV values. We didn’t reach to the PID values yet when we saw these inconsistencies.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Does that mean get however many rotations it needs to reach to the highest point and linearize it? Wouldn’t that still cause some discrepancy between the actual linear height and the height that our graphs report?

Yes. Feedforwards alone has literally 0 ability to reject disturbances, and will have poor performance outside of simulations because your model is never perfect (along with other annoyances such as latency and time delay).

Some people in FRC like to treat feedfoward as it its magic and makes everything just work, but that is just completely wrong. It improves transient performance, but has 0 effect on system stability. Feedback control is required to stabilize the system around your setpoint which is the issue you ran into.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked:
So we tried doing your tips and nothing is working now. For some reason our elevator is barely budging from its home position. We logged the voltage, current, encoder, and desired setpoints, which I attached below. We noticed that the two motors running the elevator immediately reached their current limit. I’m assuming this is the issue, but we do not know where to go from here.

Encoder/PositionSetpoint Graph Current Graph Video of Elevator

Is the sound in the video of the elevator the elevator itself or somebody nearby using an angle grinder? Also, what gear ratio is your elevator and how heavy is it. If you are hitting the current limit immediately, you likely have a mechanical issue.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Yes, that was an angle grinder in the background. Sorry about that . It’s a 1:1 ratio, and it’s not that heavy. Probably around 5-8 pounds. But here’s an update that may be good: we ran a test on the motors and realized that they needed more current to move the elevator, so we changed our current limit to 80, and it moved. We were worried the high current would destroy the motors but saw that the current was only high as it moved to a certain position. (Current dropped down to ~50 when the elevator was holding its position, so I don’t think our motors will mess up.). We are trying to manually tune it again, so we’ll see if it works out in our next meeting on Monday.

Sounds like the elevator is significantly undergeared, because elevators shouldn’t need that much current to barely start moving. 1:1 is incredibly low, especially on a cascade lift which creates an N:1 upduction after the motor.

Being undergeared makes you slower than being correctly geared because acceleration is extremely important. If possible, I would suggest using amb to find a new gear ratio that is more appropriate, and pick slightly higher than what it spits out. Going lower makes the system slow due to low acceleration, while going excessively high makes the controls problem actually harder due to latency and discretization effects.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Is there any chance you have both motors fighting each other now? One trying to move in one direction while the other tries to move in the other?

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
reca.lc is also really nice for a variety of FRC -relevant mechanism analyses.  Here is one example of an elevator analysis .  This one has two NEO motors and is assuming that the motors are trying to lift 20 pounds  over 25 inches using 25 chain on a 22T sprocket.  For a cascaded elevator, the lifting weight of the inner stage is doubled and the lifting height is half of the inner stage lifting height.

I wouldn’t go less than a 5:1 reduction on the two NEO motors, which only gives a 63 lb stall limit at 40A in this made-up example which might or might not reasonably represent your elevator.  A 9:1 reduction would be nicer to the motors in this example by keeping the current down when holding the elevator at position and would still enable quite fast elevator movement.

Belal_4641:

we noticed one motor rotation does not translate to a specific linear distance (Ex, one rotation was 2.25 in, but four rotations were 13 in of linear distance

This is a huge problem you should be looking to solve before worrying about controls.  How are you lifting the elevator?  I couldn’t tell from your video.  If you are doing something like wrapping cable or rope around a spool, you could be getting overlap in your wraps which changes the effective diameter of the spool.  Overlap tends to be unpredictable, which destroys the possibility of precise control of your elevator.  If you are lifting with chain or belt, motor rotations to elevator height should be a very linear relationship and even slight deviations would indicate something wrong with your mechanism.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Not sure if we can put a new gear ratio with the amount of time we have left for competition, but I’ll let the team know about this.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: No, they shouldn’t be. We’ll double check next meeting, though.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Belal_4641:

Not sure if we can put a new gear ratio with the amount of time we have left for competition

You don’t have much choice.  Even if direct-drive or 1:1 can just manage to lift your elevator with an 80A limit on the motors, you are likely to cook the motors trying to hold the elevator at position and you are unlikely to have good elevator height control.  Get all hands on deck, modify the design to add reduction on the elevator drive, and implement at light speed.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, we couldn’t get approval to do it. Is there any other alternatives? How much does this affect elevator height control? We verified that our Neo motors are using 50-60 Amps while holding the elevator in position, so that shouldn’t fry the motors? They only use 80 Amps when moving.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
What you describe sounds like it will very likely damage the motors.  Have you looked at the locked rotor data for the NEO?

Note that the failure here is thermal and the time-to-failure doesn’t immediately “reset” the moment you stop applying current.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
The locked-rotor testing shows that you are well into the danger zone holding at 60A.  You are going to run into more problems than that, though.

You are running those Spark MAXes with a maximum 40A breaker.  The Rev breakers are a bit notorious for being generous with the current, but they will likely trip within 5 seconds at 80A.  You might get away with not periodically tripping a breaker, but then again, you might not.

The most likely issue you are going to have is browning out your robot.  If you are trying to hold your elevator up with two motors pulling 50A each, that 100A is going to pull down your bus voltage at least 1.8V and likely more.  Any driving that you do while moving or holding the elevator up is going to add to the current draw and voltage drop.  It’s easy to attempt to pull well in excess of 100A while driving.  Even if you manage to stay out of the brownout zone, your driving is going to be affected by very significant drops in bus voltage.

Whomever is disapproving a change is setting your team up for failure.

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked: Ok, we’re going to order some gearboxes. Hopefully we get them by Wednesday. Thanks for the insight! Hopefully we run into no tuning issues by then. If we do, we know where to go

posts.name: Belal Alchahrour
posts.cooked:
Alright, so we were able to put a 5:1 gear ratio on the elevator, which made our current stay well below 40 A. We were able to tune the elevator, and it smoothly went up to its desired position.

But… we have a code issue now. The elevator only works the first time we tell it to move to a position. After that, it doesn’t go to other setpoint positions . For example, if enable the robot and make the elevator move to L2, it moves perfectly; however, as soon as we want to go to another position from L2 (like its home position), the elevator crashes down. (It’s as if the updating desired setpoint wants to go to negative infinity).

Here’s a couple of graphs. The Blue line is the relative encoder position; yellow line is desired position; and red line is the position error. (One of the graphswe commented out the “setVoltage()” method to see what the desired position does which is why the encoder line appears not to move):

Graph 1 Graph 2

Here is our code again so you don’t have to scroll up and find it in the thread. A couple of things we suspect is that it’s maybe something to do with the m_controller.calculate() method. It could also be an issue with how we have our commands set up maybe?

And since I haven’t said so, thank y’all for all the help!! Truly the best!

accepted_answer.excerpt:
There is a lot to digest in all the code.  However, a couple things pop out to me. 
It appears that haven’t done any scaling of your elevator position or velocity.  I see direct use of  encoder position (which is in rotations) and encoder velocity (which is in rotations per minute).  Are you passing…
